utterances: Because you kept being asked questions about it.

Billy Collins, thank you so much for your time today.
We appreciate it.
Well, thanks for having me in, and thanks also for devoting this time to poetry.
I think it's very important.
All right.
And thanks to all of the poets who called in and wrote us emails.
The new collection by Billy Collins is called ""Horoscopes for the Dead,"" and he joined us today from the studios of member station, KUOW, in Seattle.
Coming up, white men and diversity, are they the problem or part of the solution?
Email us: talk@npr.org.
We'll talk with the ""Ask the White Guy"" columnist.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Negotiators are getting ready to make an important play in what has become a very long game to curb Iran's nuclear plan.
U.S.
Secretary of State John Kerry met today with Iran's foreign minister.
And Russia's Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov will also be joining the talks in Vienna.
Tomorrow is the deadline for diplomats to come up with a deal.
NPR's Peter Kenyon has been following the talks and reports that even at the 11th hour, negotiators are still trying to figure out if they can meet the deadline or if yet another extension is needed.
Diplomats here won't rule out a last-minute agreement, but the likelihood of an extension seems to be growing.
One Iranian news agency quotes a member of the Iranian delegation as saying talks on an extension could begin tonight.
Ideally, any extension would be part of a framework that includes new evidence of progress.
But analyst Ali Vaez at the International Crisis Group says it's tricky even finding limited compromises on the big issues remaining.
Shrinking Iran's ability to produce nuclear fuel on the one side and lifting international sanctions on the other.
He says while it's possible to identify concessions on the Iranian side, getting the West to lift sanctions is more of a challenge.
This really boils down to the fundamental problem that we have in the talks at this point, which is the difference in the nature of the parties' concessions.
Meaning that it's much more difficult to turn sanctions on and off than to turn centrifuges on and off.

What negotiators have said about sanctions is that under an agreement, Iran would eventually see all sanctions lifted, but at the beginning, a suspension of some sanctions is the best Tehran can hope for.
This appears to be sinking in in Tehran.
Conservative students and politicians are calling on President Hassan Rouhani not to accept any deal that involves suspending sanctions instead of lifting them entirely.
Vaez says this points to another misunderstanding in some quarters.
It would be wrong, he says, to assume that the pragmatic, engaging Rouhani has a lower threshold for an acceptable deal than Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
He says Rouhani is the former nuclear negotiator himself and is haunted by the ghosts of failure a decade ago.
Because he is the one who in 2003 to 2005 made concrete concessions for the promises of incentives that never came.

If President Rouhani goes back to sell the deal and says I've accepted all these restrictions that are concrete, are immediate, but the West has only suspended sanctions, people will accuse him of being naive.
This history of mistrust flows both ways.
Critics in the region and the West argue that Iran almost certainly had a nuclear weapons program in the past.
And a current or future covert program is a critical danger.
Here's how nuclear expert David Albright put it recently.
It's a very big mistake if you don't deal with these past questions about Iran's work on nuclear weapons.
I would say no deal until Iran has shown concrete progress on addressing these past military nuclear issues.
At the moment, negotiators are preparing for a very long day tomorrow and at least the possibility of more long days to come.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Vienna.
That raises a lot of concerns.
Any improvement could be due to the placebo effect, or other factors besides the stem cell therapy, and may not lead to longer-term functional gains.
No rigorous controlled clinical trials were carried out before the treatment was offered to patients.
No research has yet been published in established peer review journals overseas.
And no one knows for sure what the possible risks might be.
(LAUGHTER)
Yeah.
A lot of jazz singers, I've noticed, recently have been stripping down their ensembles.
Maybe it's the economy or something.
But, you know, I think it really suits Rebecca Martin well.
I mean, she's made fuller, sort of singer-songwriter albums with her original compositions.
But this one is, you know, all jazz standards.
And, you know, it's really hard to do that right.
I mean, especially without any backup.
I mean, you have to phrase everything so correctly.
You know, the way she articulates a T or ends a word.
She doesn't improvise much, if at all, here.
She just focuses on expressing that melody.
And when she gets it right - and I think that's pretty often - I think it's quite exquisite.
(Soundbite of song, ""For All We Know"")
(Singing) We won't stay the night until (unintelligible)...
Amazing, gorgeous music.
Music from Rebecca Martin.
That's ""For All We Know"" from her new record, ""When I Was Long Ago.
I'm speaking with NPR Music's jazz producer, Patrick Jarenwattananon.
And he's brought us a few new jazz records that have crossed his desk.
And, Patrick, I'm hearing some tuba sneaking up behind us.
Can't go wrong with tuba.
What are we hearing?
This is from the composer, Henry Threadgill who plays saxophone and flute.
And his current band is called Zooid.
Zooid.
Isn't that something biological?
Yeah.
I'm not a biologist, but I do read that a zooid is a single cell that can move independently within a larger organism.
Aha.
So, think of like a sperm cell.
It has a certain autonomy within the body.
Mm-hmm.
And you can think of the soloists in this band in the same way.
They move around and occasionally hook up with the rest of the band, sort of move in and out.
And it kind of seems chaotic but, you know, it sort of staggers and lurches.
And it kind of provides these really interesting dissonances but kind of grooves too.
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
Absolutely.
(Soundbite of music, ""Extremely Sweet William"")
There's that single cell moving independently in a larger organism.
What kind of composer thinks up something like that?
I mean, we heard the tuba and then you got the flute coming in.
It's an unusual composer who decides to do something like this.
But I think if you sort of let it sink in and listen to it, you might like all of a sudden find yourself kind of like nodding along, like, yeah, I kind of get this.
Henry Threadgill, he came up in Chicago.
He was a member of the AACM, which is the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians.
And this is an important musician's collective that started in the 1960s.
And throughout his entire career, he's always had unorthodox-looking bands.
And he's always sort of teetered them on the boundaries of composition and improvisation.
I find myself really drawn to it.
I mean, who else does this.
(Soundbite of music, ""Extremely Sweet William"")
That's Henry Threadgill and his band Zooid with the track, ""Extremely Sweet William.
And, Patrick, I understand this next band is also from Chicago.
Yeah.
There's always been a really happening and innovative jazz scene in Chicago.
Some of these guys play in rock bands, too, but they have a jazz project and it's a really good one.
It's called Herculaneum.
(Soundbite of music, ""Temporary Orca"")
Herculaneum is coming out with a fourth record soon.
It's called ""Olives and Orchids."" In general, they've got really interesting horn arrangements and kind of happening grooves.
I think of something like Charles Mingus's music if maybe he lived in the 2000s and listened to rock music and, you know, Balkan brass bands and everything that's come since.
And when they improvise, they tend to get a bit freaky.
(Soundbite of music, ""Temporary Orca"")
These guys, I'm assuming are - if they're also sort of like, rock musicians - they're probably a little younger, right?
Yeah.
They're certainly on the younger end.
I think they're in their 20's and 30's.
They're also white guys, too, whereas Henry Threadgill came form a musical community Southside of Chicago, very aware of its blackness, it's African-American heritage.
